query: What did the CPS think about reasonable punishment when discussing the bill?
summary: The CPS thought that the law should reflect contemporary society and the law was evolutionary in nature, and should be changed to reflect the way in which people behaved within society. In respect of children in particular, they had section 58 of the Children Act 2004, which did make it a defence for a person accused of assaulting a child to argue that it was a case where they were acting only so as to impose reasonable punishment upon the child. In that sense, matters were clarified, because up until that point it was not entirely clear. But the more general criminal legislation, such as the Offences Against the Person Act, did provide specifically for adults and children alike not to be subject to physical assault.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the divergence between the law in England and Wales?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that there was a spectrum of offending between the law in England and Wales, and the CPS had a specific provision that took account of the potential divergence of Welsh law. In terms of how they would approach it within the Crown Prosecution Service in Cymru-Wales, the approach would be along the lines of working with Kwame and his colleagues to make sure that the guidance that they issue nationally suited both England and Welsh. They would build themselves up to come up with the appropriate guidance according to the circumstances.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about updating the guidance on the divergence of criminal law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought they would need to update the guidance, and it would go back to the application of the evidential stage, before the public interest stage. They might have some light-touch guidance around that. It was probably the first time that there had been an obvious divergence between English and Welsh law, and so they should be aware of it. However, within the existing guidance, it could be dealt with.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before making
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it would not necessarily be helpful to see the draft changes to CPS guidance on the public interest test before making the final decision. What they would envisage was that they would simply want to take the present public interest factors, which were set out, in his view, very clearly in the code for Crown prosecutors, and they would provide a degree of detail around those that relates more specifically to the issues that they were discussing here.

query: What did Barry Hughes think of the criminal law in Wales and England diverging in this particular instance
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked Barry Hughes if there were other offences in Wales that didn't exist in England, but they didn't crop up very often. Barry Hughes answered that there were some, but the fact that you drive across the border into Scotland and commit an offence that you won't commit in England was possibly more significant for the general public.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the implementation of the law?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that they needed to maintain the type of dialogue that they had built up with the Welsh Government and colleagues there. They needed involvement from Iwan, for example, and the strategic implementation group. They had other members of his staff who were involved in the other work streams that feed through to that, and they believed that that involvement would ensure that they were sufficiently interconnected.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the practical and possibly financial implications for his workforce in this?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that if this legislation went through, there would be minor financial consequences for his workforce in this, but he did not see any significant financial consequences in the period between now and the Bill becoming law other than the time of themselves in discussing this today. He believed that they would be able to keep a clear track on those and, obviously, they would wish to keep the situation under review, and they would reach a period of time after whatever—12, 18 months, maybe 24 months—where they would look back to see how they were doing with it all.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the interests of the child when discussing the public interest test?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the best interests of the child would be taken into account in considering whether to go forward with a prosecution. The essence of the public interest test was about proportionality, and trying to come up with an approach that was proportionate to the offending. It was not determinative, nor was it determinative in cases where we prosecute for adult defendants inflicting some form of assault upon adult victims. In circumstances where both parents, arguably, were the suspects, they probably wouldn't be asking them. They would find another way, and they would talk with the police to ensure that they were informed about how the child felt about what had happened.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about out-of-court disposals?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that there were a great many offences or reports of crime that did not reach the CPS because they were dealt with by way of an out-of-court disposal. However, it was still unclear as to what was a more appropriate disposal than a prosecution. There was a spectrum of offending, and it would be simpler and clearer to have fewer types of disposals with more clarity about what each one of them involved.

query: Summarize the discussion about the unintended consequences from Siân Gwenllian.
summary: Siân Gwenllian mentioned that under the new law, or the proposed law, would one unintended consequence be that, if someone living in Wales who couldn't use the reasonable punishment defence would their life prospects be different compared to those people in England, who would be able to use that defence? Barry Hughes was not sure it was for him to say whether there should be a duty or not. He thought the greater the level of awareness, the more likely it was that the Act, if passed, would achieve its intentions. However, there would have been an element of choice.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases
summary: Barry Hughes thought that the risk of malicious reporting against parents involved in private family law cases was extremely unlikely because they already had a well-developed approach to dealing with the way in which they evaluated the evidence from parties who may well have a particular position that they wanted to reinforce, sometimes through exaggeration of basic facts and sometimes through fabrication. And, in his experience, the police were much more sensible these days than they may have been 20 years ago, in terms of trying to get cases charged in order to meet some notional target.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the costs of prosecuting cases made possible by the Bill?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that there was a huge body of legislation out there that outlaws certain offences, and they probably prosecuted 5 per cent of those in any given year. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions was, for him, not a reason not to signify that certain behaviour was or was not acceptable. Moreover, the criminal law provided a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. Therefore, it would not be a barrier.

query: Summarize the discussion about the speech enhancement algorithm
summary: PhD A explained that he had been working on a signal subspace approach for speech enhancement. He had been taking spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering from the France Telecom system and applying LDA on top of that. The results showed that the baseline improved by twenty-two percent by just putting the endpoint into the model. He also found that the on-line normalization did not improve the performance much.

query: Summarize the discussion about the improvements in the data structure.
summary: The team discussed the improvements in the data structure. The well-matched condition was finally shown to be better than France Telecom for mismatch and high-mismatch, but it was still slightly worse for well-matched. The team also discussed whether spectral subtraction should be done on the FFT bins or on the Mel energies. They decided to do both.

query: Summarize the discussion about Wiener filter and signal subspace
summary: The team discussed the pros and cons of combining Wiener filter and signal subspace with spectral subtraction. The professor pointed out that the former did not work very well with the poor SNR conditions and the latter did not perform well with noisy speech. The latter was due to the fact that noise was added to the data by additive noise. The team discussed how they could combine the two approaches to improve the performance of their model. They came up with the idea of using a combination of on-line normalization and Wiener filtering.

query: What did the professor think about the data driven filters?
summary: The professor thought that the data driven filters were a good idea, but he was concerned that they might throw away too much information. query: Summarize the discussion about the data structure and the probabilities

The next phase would be the design of the look and feel of the product and the user interface design.

query: Summarize the discussion about the final design.
summary: The team decided to use a scroll-wheel with voice recognition, a plastic cover with rubber finishing, and some additional buttons. They also decided not to use LCD and to use regular chips instead of the advanced version of the chip. The final design was spongy and rubber.

query: What did the group discuss about the status of the Welsh baccalaureate qualification?
summary: According to Sian Gwenllian, most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh baccalaureate, what does it offer, and whether that's developing the skills that employers require is very questionable. Also, according to Dr Rachel Bowen, it varies by size of employer as well. Where there are larger employers, who've got people who are able to follow policy developments across the education spectrum, they may have more capacity to follow changes, get up to date with how Welsh education is evolving.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM suggested that they should review the qualification, and the voice of employers should be a key part of that review, so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills had more of a role within the qualification. Dafydd Evans agreed and suggested that the Welsh baccalaureate was a perfect opportunity to tie in employers into schools and colleges and get that time and input from them into schools in a far more co-ordinated way. However, it was argued that the aim was an excellent one, but they had lost their way in terms of what they did present at the end of the day, and having more input from employers would be a great help.

query: Summarize the discussion about the Welsh bac and its role in preparing learners for employment.
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, one of the problems is that there are a number of priorities. It's a valid priority for the Welsh Government for everyone to get a C grade in the core subjects. But that eats into the time that they have to teach young people. The Welsh baccalaureate, where it works really well, does help prepare them, I think, for employment, but it's not for everyone, because some people have to do the other things. So, it needs to be reviewed, to look at how they could make skilled and employable people. Suzy Davies thought that the vision of this was created as almost something that could have the status of something like a Duke of Edinburgh award without necessarily being a compulsory qualification; what was important was that the learners got the skills.

query: What did the group discuss about the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: The group discussed the different levels of the Welsh baccalaureate. At level 1 and level 2, it was not what they would call a crowd puller in colleges, but at level 3 it was more, especially for A-levels, because it could help them get into university. At the same time, at level 4, four A-Levels were better for some areas, like dentistry, for example, and some of the other Seren-type activities.

query: What did the meeting discuss about universities' attitude towards the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Kay Martin, some of the universities are not valuing the Welsh baccalaureate. In some areas, and certainly the local universities around here—University of South Wales, Cardiff Metropolitan University—value it in a great number of subjects, particularly in sport, when their students went to Cardiff Met, and business studies, when our learners went to USW. However, in other areas, it was mixed, and it depended on the admissions tutors and the areas that they were going into in universities. And the important point that Dafydd raised was that there was a lot of repetition there in school, pre 16 to post 16 at those levels as well. So, learners don't come in banging at the door saying, 'We want to do Welsh bac because it's exactly the same or very similar to what we did when we were in school.'

query: What did the group discuss about the comparable qualifications?
summary: Julie Morgan AM asked whether the Welsh baccalaureate was trying to be all things to all men. Dafydd Evans answered that it was comparable, as long as it was right for that learner's future. But if a learner wanted to go into a particular sector and it was not accepted, then it would not be comparable. And the investment they had to put into WorldSkills was huge. So, they put a lot of time—to get somebody into a Worldskills competition was not just a couple of hours a week, it wasn't just the normal curriculum—they had extra time. They were more able and talented vocational learners, and that was more valuable to those learners and I think it was more valid for employers.

query: What did the group discuss about the skills being developed in the Welsh bac?
summary: According to Dr Rachel Bowen, the baccalaureate approach was best at producing independent, inquiry-based learners who had the skills to look to teachers not as sources of information but just for guidance. The chances were that they had lost some of that by trying to fit it into being a specific qualification. However, Nick Brazil thought that it was debatable if all the skills that were supposed to be developed in the Welsh bac were being developed fully.

query: What did Julie Morgan think about universal adoption?
summary: Julie Morgan thought that the decision in individual colleges not to offer baccalaureate was down to the opportunity that it presented them to attract students, particularly from sixth forms, where students may be obliged to do the bac. However, she did want to test something, because they had had witnesses who said that it would be a good idea because it reduced the amount of competition and advantage that certain institutions had. In the majority of colleges across Wales, it was absolutely not used as a recruitment tool, because most of them, as you see, they value the Welsh baccalureate.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about the bac?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that the baccalaureate should be seen as an important part of creating a rounded individual ready for employment. It was part of what the college's curriculum offered—there was no doubt about that—and then people would make a choice according to what they needed to do to actually progress to the future. The qualifications were well catered for. There was a big range, and some really high achievers coming into the sector as well. So, he did not think it was a case of squeezing things out.

query: What did Nick Brazil think about the pupils who came to the school because they didn't have to
summary: According to Nick Brazil, the pupils who came to the school because they didn't have to do the Welsh baccalaureate exam was one of the first questions that people always asked. He explained that the learners usually had sometimes had not the best experience pre 16 and that's why they asked the question straight away. Education was about offering the range and offering it correctly. If the school didn't offer the full range, which, sometimes—if you, obviously, limit and made qualifications compulsory, that can limit the choice of opportunities as well.

query: What did the group think about introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh bac
summary: Dawn Bowden AM asked whether introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate would actually help in some way in improving its status and perception and so on. Dafydd Evans answered that there were certainly instances of that happening, there was no doubt. However, it did make it into quite an intensive selling process for colleges when they had got to overcome that negative perception. As people had said already, it was possible to talk parents and learners round, but then that's time spent having to do that selling job when they should be talking about other things.

query: Summarize the discussion about the communication and the steer that everyone's getting from Welsh Government on
summary: According to Kay Martin, they were supposed to have a policy of universal adoption, but that didn't really seem to be happening on the ground. Now, if that was rolled out across the board, teachers in particular were going to struggle to deliver some of these commercial and world-skilled, global areas, because it's not their bag. Therefore, they needed to spend less time in checking what they've done on assessment and more time in the doing, and the experiential learning that they need to do, rather than it being too much of a paper exercise. They needed to incorporate that better.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the feedback on the draft curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM thought that there had been broad support for the curriculum changes that they were proposing. There had been a concerted effort and a plan drawn up to try and ensure that there was as much engagement, knowledge and opportunity as possible. The draft curriculum was based on four purposes, four purposes would be set out in the legislation, as well as putting in law the areas of learning and experience that you'll all be familiar with. Then, below that, they were going to legislate for a number of the cross-curricular aspects—so, the literacy, the numeracy and the digital competency—as well as some elements where they had already said that they was going to make that statutory, so, for instance, above and beyond what Graham Donaldson would have put in his original reports. They would also be looking to include in legislation provision for a statutory framework setting out their approach to progression in each of the AoLE areas.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the religious education and relationships and sexuality education?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that they had demonstrated that they were listening to people, that there had been concern expressed about certainty and having a national approach on some of these issues, and they had taken steps to address that and they would continue to reflect with their partners who were co-constructing this with them. There was certainly a need to modernise RE; some people perceived the current curriculum as a bit old-fashioned. And there were many responses that were concerned about and emphasised the need to respect parents' views.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that the curriculum should be published in January 2020, so that schools would have the opportunity to be really engaging in it. However, there were some issues raised about potential challenges with staff in talking about issues that they perhaps personally did not agree with with regard to this curriculum. Therefore, Kirsty Williams would be making a statement in the near future of their intentions on how to respond to these issues.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the segregation?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM thought that there was no evidence that the new curriculum would lead to a segregation. She believed that it would only be as good as the four enabling elements that surrounded it, which were strong leadership of the schools that ensured that there is no segregation, that had high expectation of all of our children, and delivered a curriculum within that setting that met the needs of the children there. Moreover, the curriculum on its own would not be enough. There would be a statutory framework to ensure that progression was the same wherever you were in Wales.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the lessons learned from Scotland?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that had arisen. Although their curriculum was not a copycat, as Kirsty Williams pointed out, they had had people who had been deeply involved in the Scottish experience as part of some of their curriculum and assessment groups and some of the advice had been in terms of developing coherence. Also, one of the critical elements was the extent to which assessment was considered at the outset alongside the curriculum content, and they had embraced experts who were involved in that process who were part of the curriculum assessment group.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the preparation for the implementation?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. The money was being made available to each and every school and had empowered headteachers to really think, 'What are the professional needs of my school and the practitioners in my school?' Because, as they had just heard from Claire, there were some schools that had been part of the pioneer process from the very beginning and therefore were further along that development chain. There were other schools that maybe were only beginning now, now that it's published, to be really engaging with the curriculum. So, there was going to clearly be an ongoing programme of preparation development and personal development, as well as anything else.

query: Summarize the discussion about the issue of teachers who are not trained in Wales.
summary: According to Kirsty, they would continue to have a system where teachers trained in Wales will teach in England and teachers who have worked in England will come across the border, as well as teachers from other parts of the world coming to teach in Wales. They would have a mix of sector—secondary, primary—but also linguistically, to just try to make sure that this works in all the different types of schools. At a regional level, they require the regions to engage with all schools through the cluster model. They did not have a monitoring system that said, "Tick every box".

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the emphasis placed on assessment for learning and progression?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought that the emphasis placed on assessment for learning and progression should be clear so that no one could drive a set of behaviours that had negative unintended outcomes. The primary purpose for assessment was for that professional to be able to know how to move that child's educational journey on. Therefore, it was absolutely clear that teachers should share assessment methods and outcomes with parents to have that conversation about what happens next.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about categorisation?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM thought that categorisation was not a way of expressing a league table of school performances; it was there to identify levels of support that a school can expect from its regional consortia. The ultimate system that they were going to get to and the ultimate arbiter and the part of the system that provided public assurance and public confidence ultimately ended in Estyn. Therefore, categorisation would stay.

query: Summarize the discussion about the Welsh dimension in the new curriculum.
summary: The Learned Society of Wales suggested that there needs to be a directory of resources to implement the Welsh dimension. Kirsty Williams agreed with that and said that they have a separate programme of work that is looking at resources that are needed to support the curriculum. The continuum for language would have to be contextualised depending on the setting where a child was being taught, and there would be progression points on that continuum to show progression both in Welsh language and in the English language.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think about the PISA?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, Wales was seen as an exemplar by the OECD, especially in terms of the partnership with the Arts Council of Wales and creative learning through the arts. That's why they were not actually going for it and showing how good they were through the PISA. They were asking enough of people at the moment and this would be an unnecessary addition to cope with.

query: What did Kirsty Williams AM think about the transition to post-16 education?
summary: Kirsty Williams AM thought that the transition to post-16 education was supported so that the systems don't clash against each other. One of the advantages of the new curriculum was to take the pedagogical principles that underpinned their approach to early years education actually further into children's educational journey, rather than the false divide that they had at the moment. They also had to consider, though, that for some children they may be out of school for reasons, and telling them that they've got to do a full curriculum may be hugely detrimental to their mental health and well-being. Therefore, any changes to qualifications should be a gateway to further study in FE, whichever type of route the child took.

query: Summarize the discussion about the functional design of the remote control.
summary: The group discussed the functional design of the remote control. It had to be original, trendy, user-friendly, and easy to use. The team had to look what the needs were, the effects of the functional and the properties of the user interface. Then they discussed the detailed design.

query: What did the group discuss about the process of drawing the animals?
summary: The group drew an elephant, a fish, a pig, a cat, a dog, a worm, and a sheep. The water was important for the drawing of the animals, so the group drew the water first. Then they drew the animals in the format of the whiteboard. After that, they made a new blank new blank page.

query: What did the group discuss about the universal remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the universal remote control should be sold for 25 Euros. The production cost were about half the price of selling price, so the profit would be fifty million Euros. However, Project Manager was not sure if it should be a universal because they sold it apart from the television and not with the television, so they had to use a big market in Europe to make a profit. The group also agreed that there should not be too many buttons on the remote control.

query: What did the group discuss about the usability of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested making the remote control the same style as the television, so that users could see more options. User Interface thought it should not be too big, because it had to have a lot of functions. Project Manager agreed, but added that it was not too expensive to put a touchscreen on it, so they could make something like mobile phones that could fold open. And the infrared thing must be from very good quality.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that a home station was a good idea because lots of people lost their remote control and didn't know where it was, so it would be convenient to put it always at the same place. However, the cost of the home station would be high, so the group decided to make it a separate option and sell it separately. The group also agreed that the remote control should be kid-proof and the on off button should be on top.

query: What did the group discuss about the folding function?
summary: The group discussed the folding function and the strength of the remote control. Project Manager thought it would be hard to make it fold open and look like a normal remote control, so they decided to keep it like a square. The group also discussed what kind of buttons they need on their remote control and what kind buttons they should have on it.

query: Summarize the discussion about collecting data for the corpus.
summary: The team discussed collecting data for the corpus. The professor suggested that they should collect data from different kinds of meetings, such as the front-end meeting, the networking group meeting, and the group meeting. The team also discussed the feasibility of collecting data from a variety of domains, including English, German, Spanish, and other languages.

query: Summarize the discussion about the disk space and the cost of the project
summary: The team discussed the amount of disk space they had available and the cost of the project. The team agreed that they were getting more space on the current disk, but it would not be enough to store all the data. They also discussed whether they should move the data from Broadcast News to another disk. The professor suggested that they could get more space from other vendors.

query: What did the team discuss about the data?
summary: The team discussed how to classify the overlapping zones in the data. The first idea they came up with was to use a sup supervised and hierarchical clustering process to classify speech and overlapping speech. The second idea they discussed was using a decision tree to classify overlapping events.

query: What did the professor think about the data structure?
summary: The professor thought that the data structure was a good starting point. He thought that it would be useful to detect the change, the acoustic change. The professor also suggested that the team should look at the spectral distortion in the PDA data to get a sense of how the different classes of speech are related to each other. He wanted to know if there was a difference in the signal-to-noise relation between the two microphones.

query: Summarize the discussion about the data structure and the data structure of the recordings.
summary: The team discussed the data structure of the recordings. They decided that they would use the same name for the speaker identifier and also in the text whenever the speaker's name is mentioned. The team also discussed whether they should delay the anonymization of the data until next week.

query: What did the team discuss about the transcript?
summary: The team discussed how to best use the transcript. The professor thought that the team should not change the names in the transcript because it would be a mistake to do so. The team also discussed whether they should keep the transcripts in the same order or bleep out certain words. They decided to keep the transcript as is for the time being.

query: Summarize the discussion about the functional requirements of the remote control.
summary: The group discussed the functional requirements of the remote control. According to the research results, seventy-five percent of the users found most remote controls ugly, eighty percent of users would spend when a remote control would look fancy, and seventy five percent of older people would spend more money for something fancy. The group agreed to make a beautiful and unique remote control, and to make it stand out by having a different colour or different shape. Besides, they agreed to keep the function simple and make good zap buttons.

query: Summarize the discussion about the working design.
summary: The group agreed that the remote control should stand out from other remote controls by having a different shape and be unique with the design. There should also be a menu button and a button to go to the channel you've been before. The group also agreed to use a mute button to indicate that the TV was working.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new remote control requirements.
summary: The team agreed that the new remote control should be made with a more intelligent chip to make it more user-friendly. They also agreed that teletext had become outdated since the popularity of the internet, so they had to skip that one and make a new one for a new market with customers younger than forty. Also, the group agreed that they should give customers some extras to make the remote control more attractive.

query: Summarize the discussion about the usability of the remote control.
summary: The group agreed that the usability of the remote control was not that good because they only had TV functions on it, so it was not useful enough to design something with speech recognition. Also, the group thought that the design was most important, so they could integrate the buttons in the design very much. Then they decided to put a light under the under the numbers and everything, so that users could see what other buttons were there.

query: Summarize the discussion about the function buttons.
summary: The group decided to use hard plastic with a colour changeable and transparent material. The buttons would be basic, like mute, mute, on-off, channel buttons, scrollwheel, num-pad and scrollwheel. There would be a menu button with arrows to navigate the menu. The group did not know how many buttons speech requires.

query: Summarize the discussion about buttons and colour.
summary: Marketing made some criteria to evaluate the model. The group agreed to make three buttons, all the colours on it, and choose green, blue and red. They also agreed to have a text button on the remote control.

query: Summarize the discussion about the features and function of the remote control.
summary: The team agreed that the remote control was easy to use, with speech function, scrollwheel, backlights, slide, backlight, and home station. The team also agreed that it was not as fast as a usual remote control, but it was still better than the average. Also, it was believed that the design of the backlight was innovative, and the colour was new. The group also agreed on the features and function of rechargeable.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the product.
summary: The team agreed that there was room for creativity in the product. However, the product was not as user-friendly as they expected it to be. Also, the price was too high, and the team was not too hard on themselves for not following the latest trends. Finally, they agreed that the team work was okay.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new ideas found.
summary: The group discussed the new ideas found during the brainstorming phase of the meeting. The new ideas included a universal device, a touchscreen, a favourite for the text, LCD screen, and touch screens for all the stuff. Also, the group agreed that the entrance of the remote control should be more to the left instead of to the right.

query: Summarize the presentation on the prototype.
summary: The prototype had a plastic body with a standard colour and a rubberised outer casing. The top screen would be an inset black and white LCD touch screen and the bottom screen would just contain the standard buttons, like the volume up and down, channel up, power on and off, and things to that effect. There would be a standard transmission with the TV using using all the standard chips. The infrared sender would be on one of the bottom layers, and the voice recognition system would be in the top section rather than the bottom.

query: Summarize the evaluation of the prototype.
summary: Marketing presented the evaluation criteria based on the market research findings about the spongy texture to the exterior and the fruit and vegetable design colours. The team rated each criterion on a seven point scale, with one being true and seven being false. The average rating for each criterion was two.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation findings.
summary: Marketing summarized the evaluation findings. The team agreed that the prototype meeting the specifications was high enough at the upper end of the scale for the company to go ahead with the production. The lowest rating they got was for the minimisation of repetitive strain injury, which was close around neutral. In terms of the cost, Industrial Designer thought they were happy with the costs on that, and they could not do much more to minimise that. The group also agreed that it was easy to locate.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the cost of the remote control should be 12.5 Euros in Euros and 25 Euros in US dollars. They also agreed that they could change the battery to a standard one instead of a kinetic one, and they could offer the voice recognition initially to business class customers. However, they decided not to change the design specification because the exchange range would make it about twelve.

query: Summarize the discussion about the team and the project.
summary: Industrial Designer thought the meeting went really well and everyone was listened to and all the points that were raised seemed to have been sorted out, although they didn't quite make the voice recognition in there. User Interface thought the teamwork was great and they had a lot of interaction and needed to bounce off each other. Marketing thought the team had done a good job in bringing things from other areas in the project.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the project.
summary: Marketing thought the project had done very well to get within budget and it still made such an innovative item that people were really going to want. However, Project Manager thought that the remit of the project was very specific and no one had put much thought into it. Therefore, they had to find a new way of raising the cash for it.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increase in exclusions.
summary: According to Sharon Davies, there were more examples of very challenging behaviour in the system in Wales, and the prevalence of ASD—autism spectrum disorder—and trying to get the learners the right provision was sometimes a challenge. However, the local authorities had been working really hard on their exclusions and working with their schools to ensure that the curriculum was broad and balanced, and accounts for every learner within the system. In terms of school accountability measures, there was a huge amount of pressure on schools to perform and the whole culture that the schools were within did play an element of it to some. Therefore, it was important to share that.

query: What did the group discuss about the financial pressures on schools?
summary: According to Sharon Davies, there was pressure, in particular with the new Act coming in, and that was going to place more pressure on the system. In addition, the additional learning needs sector was being adversely affected, but it was not sure whether it was being worse affected, because they were talking now about a wider age range—doing up to 25 as well. Moreover, there were financial pressures there, but they had got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, was devolved to schools. However, it was difficult to know how headteachers and governing bodies would react. If they were under pressure financially or in terms of performance measures, they would react in a particular way.

query: What did Nick Williams think about the transition arrangements?
summary: According to Nick Williams, the more challenging learners were the ones who were coming to the end of their statutory education, so they were looking more at how they transit, then, into further education and colleges and so on. It was far, far more difficult when they were 15, 16 to get them back into mainstream. So, they had recognised that, so that they had their staff working very closely with the schools. There was an integration through a part-time timetable back into school, and they continued to support them during that process.

query: What did Nick Williams think about the quality assuring, monitoring or evaluating the EOTAS provision
summary: According to Nick Williams, a lot of the additional provision was provision they also used, in their experience. So, if it's MTP or something through the college, like a mechanics course or something like that, they were probably using it ourselves. However, they didn't want to make it too difficult, so that they haven't got any providers coming forward either. It was a little bit of a balancing act. First and foremost, safeguarding was at the forefront of their thinking.

query: What did the meeting discuss about home tuition?
summary: According to Lynne Neagle, the purpose of the question was around home tuition that was commissioned by the local authority, but Nick Williams was not sure if that was a consistent answer for local authorities. He thought it was about getting that money following the learners and so on, and that shared ownership of the learner that the schools needed to keep, because they wanted them reintegrated back into schools. Therefore, it was in all their interests to do the very best for these learners.

query: What were the challenges associated with the curriculum?
summary: According to Nick Williams, in general, they were satisfied with the way the curriculum was being delivered. However, in some areas, they could not give a definitive answer on, because they were not able to give a definite one of what's happening across Wales. Where home tuition was provided through the local authority, as had been discussed, there should be safeguards there to make sure that that quality assurance took into account what the pupil was receiving.

query: What did the group discuss about the provision?
summary: The group agreed that there was a disconnect between what should be happening and what actually was happening. The basic numeracy, literacy and well-being stuff was taking place, but there was discrepancy of provision, even in local authority commissioned EOTAS provision. Moreover, there were very small numbers of staff working in that provision, and they needed a group of people in the future to fill those gaps. The biggest challenge was the capacity. There really wasn't the capacity for them to access professional training. However, the most recent inspection was very positive, and not that they were being complacent.

query: What did the meeting discuss about the lack of mental health support in mainstream schools?
summary: According to Nick Williams, there was a general deficit in child and adolescent mental health services, for example. There were three health boards over the footprint of the south-west and mid Wales region. Therefore, it was probably a more general issue there that would, in turn, translate into pupils who had got additional needs, whether they were in EOTAS, PRU or wherever. And they needed to look at the system holistically to be more prepared to deal with challenging behaviour.

query: Summarize the discussion about the increasing number of children and young people being excluded from school.
summary: Dr Ian Johnson thought it was very concerning that they were seeing increases amongst younger children in particular. A lot of the evidence they were hearing was quite anecdotal, so it tended to be around the behavioural issues or underlying issues, and there was a lot of discussion about the adverse childhood experiences agenda and how that was affecting young people. So, he thought they needed to dig a bit deeper and understand the story behind that and whether there's a specific reason why schools were doing that, related to the accountability measures.

query: What did the group discuss about the support provided to pupils who were at risk of becoming EOT
summary: The group agreed that it was important to recognise the impact of adverse childhood experiences and how that could help to drive distress and suicidal ideation. They also agreed that the whole-school approach, which was something that had been discussed within this committee, as part of the 'Mind over matter' work, was hugely important. However, there was a concern about the progress on EOTAS and PRU within the new curriculum.

query: What did Dr Ian Johnson think about the impact of school-related issues on children?
summary: Dr Ian Johnson thought that there was a gap there regarding how young people were experiencing this within the school environment and in general. There were a number of potential reasons for that. It could be the socio-economic profile, because exclusions, et cetera, were substantially higher amongst those who were eligible for free school meals, and in many parts of Wales the socioeconomic profile of a Welsh-medium education school was slightly different. Also, it was a concern, if children weren't registered with any school, how they would get back into the schooling environment, if that's what people thought was best for them. Dr Ian Johnson believed that the whole-school approach guidance needed to be statutory, because they would otherwise reach some quite uneven outcomes.

query: What did Dr Ian Johnson think about the whole-school approach?
summary: Dr Ian Johnson thought that the importance of a whole-school approach, and that being statutory, was important because that would ensure that everybody within the school community had that knowledge and awareness and knew what to do and where to signpost people. Also, he thought that children in EOTAS situations were usually more vulnerable than others, and therefore there was a need to prioritise their well-being and their mental health.

query: Summarize the discussion about the new project requirements.
summary: Firstly, the new project requirements were that the remote control should only be used for television, because teletext was out of date and internet was replacing teletext. Secondly, the product should be aimed at customers younger than forty. Thirdly, the corporate image should be recognisable in the product.

query: What did the group discuss about the energy-friendly components?
summary: Industrial Designer thought infrared was the most important component because it could be used to communicate with almost every TV set. User Interface thought volume and zap buttons were the most used, so the remote control should have the perfect design for those only those buttons. query: What did the group discuss about the remote control with the new features?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed to make the basic mould out of plastic but have a rubber cover that goes over, which would give the spongy feel and allow them to have different fasciae for the phone. Project Manager proposed to use pens with the grip to pull the fascia off. User Interface proposed to have a touch screen on the remote control.

query: What did the group discuss about the R_S_I_ when discussing the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the R_S_I could be attached to the remote control so that users could use their fingers to press the buttons instead of pressing down on them. The group also agreed that it would be good to have a contrast between the rubber and the plastic, so that people could open it up and see something quite fancy looking inside.

query: Summarize the discussion about the design of the remote control.
summary: Firstly, the team took the input from the previous meeting, especially from the marketing and industrial design, to check on the customer needs and feasibility. Secondly, they checked into competitors and found that the only common feature was channel control and volume control, and the rest buttons were in a very disorganized and they were not consistent with other models. Thirdly, they decided to have a G-U-I interface in the middle of the flip-top, which was a good example of graphic user interface.

query: What did the group discuss about voice recognition?
summary: The group agreed that there were too many cluttered buttons in the remote control, for example the volume and channel control buttons. Also, there was a mail mentioning that the division had developed a new speech recognition feature and customers would like to have the feature of finding it. The group agreed to check into the financial feasibility of incorporating this at a low cost. They also agreed to take inspiration from fruit colours, like the vibrant colours of red chilli and tomato red.

query: What did the group discuss about the components?
summary: The group decided to use LCD screen, rubberised buttons, rubber casing for the plastic shell, a variety of designs and rubber as a padding or for the grip to add to the design.

query: What did the team discuss about the rubberised cover when discussing the design of the remote control?
summary: The rubberised cover would be cheap to produce and it could be slipped on easily. The team would use fruit and vegetable colours for the rubber cover and the case itself would be plastic. The rubber cover could be retouchable so that users could change it every time.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the product?
summary: The group discussed the cost of the product and decided that voice recognition was not feasible, so they could go for a whistle instead. The group also discussed whether to reject the idea of a beeper for a location in favour of voice recognition, but they decided to find out more about cost afterwards.

query: Summarize the discussion about the project plan.
summary: Project Manager announced that they were going to develop a new product, a television remote control, which should be original, trendy and user-friendly. They would use a project method during this development, which consisted of three different design stages: functional design, conceptual design and the detailed design.

query: What did the group discuss about the whiteboard?
summary: The group agreed that the whiteboard was like a regular whiteboard and that they could work together on it while they were in the meetings. The profit they were looking for for this product was fifty million Euros, which was quite a number. The production cost should not be more than twelve Euros fifty, so they should keep that in mind during the development.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the interoperability of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that a modern remote control should control a diverse subset of equipment, such as DVD players, cell phones, video and audio equipment. Industrial Designer also suggested that the remote should work on different TVs or even different devices. However, Industrial Designer did not know about the cost-effectiveness of using infrared and Bluetooth.

query: What did the group discuss about the technical function of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed that the remote control should be able to change the state of the TV by pressing the button. User Interface answered that it should only change the TV's state. Project Manager asked whether there should be a restriction for the range, the operating range too. Industrial Designer suggested that infrared should be restricted to remote controls that were not pointed at the TV. However, User Interface argued that it was quite disturbing when users always had to point directly to the TV, so infrared should not be restricted.

query: What did the group discuss about the remote control?
summary: Marketing thought most most things have already been said, like control multiple devices and infrared might be an issue. Project Manager agreed and pointed out that lots of devices already use infrared so they would probably have to implement that. User Interface suggested that the buttons for volume or whatever should be visible in dark so that the user could understand what they were doing without looking at the buttons. Industrial Designer agreed and proposed a display on the remote control so that users could see functions.

query: What did the group discuss about the cost of the product?
summary: The group agreed that the cost price of the product was very low and that it would not be a high high-end product. However, Bluetooth might be a problem because it was use a lot of the time. The group also agreed that they could not use Bluetooth all the time, twenty four hours a day.
